授業目的: This course focuses on concepts, theories, and empirics on corporate governance on a COIL (collaborative online international learning) framework with a particular reference to Japan,  and an emerging economy, Bangladesh. In this course, the students will learn the bank-based monitoring system, popularly known as the integrated monitoring system deployed by Japan’s main bank, Bank of Japan, and the Ministry of Finance, to ensure effective governance on corporations. Simultaneously, the course will examine the market-based monitoring system practiced in the USA and the U.K. The course will also shed light on the governance system of an emerging economy, considering Bangladesh as a case. A professor from the University of Dhaka would offer four sessions to discuss Bangladesh’s corporate governance practices with some of his research students. The course will review the efficacy of the three pillars of corporate governance, such as board composition, ownership structure, and audit structure, to examine their applicability in Japanese culture. The course will also discuss how governance mechanisms impact family and non-family firms, corporate social behavior, and global citizenship.
到達目標: After completing the course, students will learn how the bank-based or creditor-based governance system and market-based governance mechanisms impact monitoring and controlling modern corporations’ opportunistic behavior. This course is useful for students who want to be a management consultant.
授業方法: This class is a pre-applying course. The class will be held in a face-to-face format. Course pedagogy includes lectures, articles, and case studies to illustrate and reinforce concepts. Students are expected to have read assigned materials before attending every class. Both instructors will supply all the reading materials in advance.
